testTitle: Life in the UK Test - Anglo-Saxons & Vikings
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering the Anglo-Saxon period, Viking invasions, and early medieval Britain including key figures, battles, and cultural developments.

questions.stem: When did the Anglo-Saxons come to Britain?

options.label: After the Romans left in 410 AD

questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons came to Britain after the Romans left around 410 AD, settling mainly in what is now England.

questions.stem: The Anglo-Saxons came from which regions?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons came from present-day Germany, Denmark, and the Netherlands. They were made up of Angles, Saxons, and Jutes.

questions.stem: What language did the Anglo-Saxons speak?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons spoke Anglo-Saxon, also known as Old English, which is the basis of modern English.

questions.stem: The Anglo-Saxons were initially pagans but later converted to Christianity.
questions.explanation: True. The Anglo-Saxons were initially pagan but gradually converted to Christianity through missionary work.

questions.stem: Who was St Augustine?

options.label: A missionary sent to convert the Anglo-Saxons

questions.explanation: St Augustine was a missionary sent by Pope Gregory the Great to convert the Anglo-Saxons to Christianity in 597 AD.

questions.stem: What were Anglo-Saxon kingdoms called?
questions.explanation: Anglo-Saxon England was divided into kingdoms such as Wessex, Mercia, and Northumbria.

questions.stem: When did the Vikings first raid Britain?
questions.explanation: The Vikings first raided Britain in 793 AD when they attacked the monastery at Lindisfarne.

questions.stem: Where did the Vikings come from?
questions.explanation: Vikings came from Norway, Sweden, and Denmark. They were also known as Norsemen or Northmen.

questions.stem: What was the Danelaw?

options.label: Area of England under Viking control

questions.explanation: The Danelaw was the area of England under Viking control, roughly covering the north and east of England.

questions.stem: King Alfred was known as 'Alfred the Great.'
questions.explanation: True. King Alfred of Wessex (871-899 AD) was the only English king to be called 'the Great' due to his military successes and reforms.

questions.stem: What did King Alfred achieve?

options.label: Defeated the Vikings in many battles

questions.explanation: Alfred defeated Vikings, established schools, created legal codes, and promoted learning. The Tower of London was built much later by the Normans.

questions.stem: What type of ships did the Vikings use?
questions.explanation: Vikings used longships, which were fast, shallow-draft vessels perfect for raids and river navigation.

questions.stem: Where did Vikings establish settlements outside Britain?
questions.explanation: Vikings established settlements in Iceland, Greenland, and even reached North America (Vinland). They never reached Australia.

questions.stem: What was the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon Chronicle was a collection of annals recording the history of the Anglo-Saxons.

questions.stem: Beowulf is an Anglo-Saxon epic poem.
questions.explanation: True. Beowulf is the most famous Anglo-Saxon epic poem, telling the story of a Scandinavian hero.

questions.stem: What was a 'thing' in Viking society?
questions.explanation: A 'thing' was a Viking assembly where free men could discuss issues and settle disputes.

questions.stem: Who was Canute (Cnut)?

options.label: A Viking king who ruled England

questions.explanation: Canute (Cnut) was a Viking king who ruled England from 1016-1035 and created a North Sea empire.

questions.stem: The Vikings only came to Britain as raiders.
questions.explanation: False. While Vikings initially came as raiders, many later settled and became farmers, traders, and craftsmen.

questions.stem: What was wergild in Anglo-Saxon law?
questions.explanation: Wergild was the compensation paid to the family of a murder victim instead of seeking revenge.

questions.stem: Anglo-Saxon society was divided into which groups?
questions.explanation: Anglo-Saxon society had nobles (earls), ordinary freemen (churls), and slaves. Priests were part of the church hierarchy.

questions.stem: What was the Sutton Hoo burial?
questions.explanation: Sutton Hoo was an Anglo-Saxon ship burial site dating from the early 7th century, possibly of King Raedwald.

questions.stem: Vikings were skilled metalworkers and traders.
questions.explanation: True. Vikings were skilled craftsmen, metalworkers, and long-distance traders who reached as far as Constantinople and North America.

questions.stem: What was the name for a Viking warrior who fought in a frenzy?
questions.explanation: Berserkers were Viking warriors who fought in a trance-like fury, often wearing bear or wolf skins.

questions.stem: Edward the Confessor was the last Anglo-Saxon king before the Norman Conquest.
questions.explanation: False. Harold Godwinson was the last Anglo-Saxon king. Edward the Confessor died in 1066, and Harold succeeded him before being killed at Hastings.
